response.answer_text: That’s not quite straightforward to answer. It’s a bit murky. Santa Claus is a bit of a conglomerate of different sources. Saint Nicholas of Myra is in there somewhere, and as an early Christian bishop, there’s certainly some christianity in there. But there are other sources, including (quite likely, but not easy to prove due to the propensity of early Christian writers to suppress pre-christian “evil” information), early Germanic deities. Here’s some information fro the great Oracle Wikipedia: Santa Claus - Wikipedia So there is a bit of christianity there, but most likely a lot of other stuff also. Bit of a mess, to be honest. Yes, I know he’s fictional. I actually prefer Terry Pratchett’s Hogfather as a figure, because he represents the raw brutal forces of nature. Santa always struck me as a bit weird. I mean, what’s with wanting small kids to sit on his knee all the time and the “Ho ho ho”? Also, what does he feed his Reindeer to make them fly? Whatever it is, I seriously doubt it’s legal. Question: Is Santa a Christian?

The so called ‘saint’ upon which the Santa Claus/St Nick/Father Christmas childrens tale in various countries is based was a Catholic saint which would make him a Christian, yes. The fat jolly American Santa was created as a sales gimmick for the Coca Cola company in the 1950’s. He’s an advertisement.
